thread.title: April may see Jio digging deeper into big 3 Telcos pie
thread.title_full: April may see Jio digging deeper into big 3 Telcos pie - The Economic Times

author: Kalyan Parbat
title: April may see Jio digging deeper into big 3 Telcos pie
text:
KOLKATA: Come April, it's likely to be Advantage Jio versus the Big 3 phone companies — Bharti Airtel , Vodafone India and Idea Cellular — if the Mukesh Ambani-run telco manages to retain just a shade over half of its 100 million customers once it starts charging, analysts and industry experts said. 

Reliance Industries chairman Mukesh Ambani on Tuesday said customers would have to pay a onetime Rs 99 fee for 'prime membership' and another Rs 303 a month to avail of all benefits in the unlimited voice-data "Happy New Year' offer. 

According to experts, customers who stay with Jio are likely to cut back usage levels sharply on their primary SIMs — be it, an Airtel , Vodafone or Idea —and possibly even downgrade to a lower plan or move to a voice-only back-up variant with their original carrier, as many would question the wisdom of paying for two subscriptions. 

Some say the top three could lose as much as 9-10 per cent of their premium customers, who typically, generate over half their revenues. 

"Round 1 with six months of free services went to Jio and Round 2 will also end up going to them if anything over 50 million trial users sign up to Jio's Prime (paidservices) by end-March," brokerage Sanford Bernstein said in a note. 

The brokerage said "Jio has set new expectations" by bringing high-speed mobile data to millions for the first time and the bar is "much higher now" than before. Analysts at Edelweiss backed the view, saying "the high data usage habit" would be a subscriber retention driver for Jio. 

Small wonder, experts believe Airtel, Vodafone and Idea could be staring at rapid customer losses and plunging revenues amid a sharp likely surge in competitive intensity unleashed by Jio's decision to offer unlimited voice calls and nearly 30 GB of data for a monthly Rs 303 from April. 

Analysts at UBS warned incumbent carriers could see "an acceleration in customer losses to Jio" in the next six weeks as subscribers are likely to take advantage of the 4G entrant's new unlimited offer, which is valid before March 31. The foreign brokerage, in fact, is keeping a close watch "on reactionary unlimited (pack) launches from incumbents to stem potential customer losses". 

Analysts at HSBC agreed incumbent telcos "don't have much choice other than matching Jio", but the brokerage voiced scepticism about Idea and Vodafone India's ability to do so immediately, given their limited 4G spectrum holdings by comparision. 

So much so, the brokerage feels incumbents may be compelled to boost data capacity on a war footing and accelerate investments in fibre backhaul with a sharper 4G focus, and also look at swiftly refarming the low 900 MHz spectrum band for fourth-generation mobile broadband services. 

Brokerage Credit Suisse, in turn, said Jio's Rs 303 per month offer is perhaps "the first unlimited voice + data plan in India that effectively puts a cap on the ARPU (average revenue per user) of all higher-end subscribers" of incumbent operators and could be ARPU dilutive. 

"Nearly 50 per cent of revenue of incumbent operators like Bharti Airtel come from subscribers with Rs 300-plus ARPU (with average levels of Rs 550-plus). Jio's Rs 303 per month plan puts an ARPU ceiling on all such subscribers," said Credit Suisse in a note. 

Industry experts agree that any effort to match Jio's tariffs could progressively shave off nearly 40-50 per cent of the revenue that Airtel, Vodafone and Idea typically generate from higher-end customers, which would hit the overall ARPU and hurt both top-line and bottom-line in the coming quarters.
